{{Infobox person | name = Pedro Llosas Badía | image = Pere Llosas i Badia a La Tradició Catalana el 1927.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Pedro Llosas Badía | birth_date = 1870 | birth_place = [[Olot]] | death_date = 1955 | death_place = Olot | body_discovered = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | residence = | nationality = [[Spain|Spanish]] | citizenship = | other_names = | known_for = politician | education = | alma_mater = | employer = | notable works = | occupation = banker | home_town = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = [[Carlism]], [[Patriotic Union (Spain)|UP]] | opponents = | boards = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relations = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = | misc = }}
'''Pedro Llosas y Badía''' ({{lang-ca|Pere Llosas i Badia}}) (1870–1955)<ref>some sources claim he was born 1872, see the official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=1-1&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2861630%29.NDIP. here], though most maintain the correct birth date is 1870, see Núria Moret i Llosas, ''El llegat documental de Pere Llosas i Badia'', [in:] ''Annals del Patronat d'Estudis Històrics d'Olot i Comarca'' 1994, p. 54, ''Biblioteca de Catalunya'' service, available [http://cataleg.bnc.cat:2082/search~S13*spi?/aLlosas%2C+Al%7Bu00ED%7Dcia/allosas+alicia/-3,-1,0,B/browse here], Lluís Costa Fernández, ''La dictadura de Primo de Rivera a Girona: premsa i societat (1923-1930)'' [PhD thesis Universitat de Girona], Girona 1994, {{ISBN|9788469427996}}, p. 188, B. de Artagan [Reynaldo Brea], ''Políticos del carlismo'', Barcelona 1912, p. 236, Isidre Molas, ''Els senadors carlins de Catalunya (1901-1923)'', Barcelona 2009, p. 14 or obituary in ''¡Arriba España!'' 03.12.55, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000277710&page=10 here]; also [[FamilySearch]], "España, bautismos, 1502-1940," database, available [https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:F5H2-4XS here]</ref> was a Spanish right-wing politician. Active in [[Catalonia]], he was first associated with the [[Carlists]] and then with the [[Miguel Primo de Rivera|Primo de Rivera]] regime. He was the longest-serving Carlist deputy from Catalonia during the [[Restoration (Spain)|Restauración]]<ref>Narciso Battle Baro and [[Josep de Suelves i de Montagut|Josep Suelves Montagut]] were other Catalan Carlists serving 4 turns in the Cortes, but in terms of monthly duration Llosas' tenure lasted longer</ref> but is known mostly as the civil governor of [[La Coruna (province)|La Coruña]] and [[Balearic Islands|Baleares]] provinces during the dictatorship.
==Family and youth== [[File:La Fiesta del Corpus en Olot by Barrau.jpg|thumbnail|left|[[Corpus Christi (feast)|Corpus Christi]], [[Olot]], 1894]] The Llosas family has traditionally been active in the Catalan textile industry as cotton [[Weaving|weavers]]; in the 19th century they established themselves in middle-low range of the local [[bourgeoisie]].<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 54</ref> Paternal grandfather of Pedro, [[Juan Llosas Pujol]], originated from [[Olot]] ([[Girona Province|Girona province]]), located in the comarca of [[Garrotxa|Alt Garrotxa]] at the [[Pyrenees|Pyrenean]] foothills.<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 53</ref> His son and Pedro’s father, [[Juan Llosas Tenas]] (died 1872), in early years left his native region for [[Albacete]], for over 20 years assisting his uncle in running a textile business.<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 54</ref> When the shop was inherited by his cousin, Albert Escubós Llosas, he returned to Olot and married Rosa Badía Trull (died 1896),<ref>''Eco de la montaña'' 31.05.96, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000133235&page=4 here], ''L’Olotí'' 31.05.96, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000223649&page=16 here]</ref> a native of [[Sallent]] ([[Barcelona province]]).<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 54</ref> The couple possessed land properties in the neighboring [[Santa Pau]] and [[Mieres, Girona|Mieres]].<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 55</ref> Pedro was the only child of the couple.<ref>Rosa Badia's certificate of death, available [http://s16.postimg.org/jv15ehv9x/dbc6794d_b07a_4a6b_a5d8_0a57760d7254.jpg here]</ref>
Except that he was very early orphaned by his father, next to nothing is known about Pedro’s early childhood in Olot, a town that became a headquarters of Carlism during the [[Third Carlist War]]. In 1882 he entered the nearby Seminario-Colegio de Santa María del Collell, originally an ecclesiastic seminary in 1876 merged with Instituto de Segunda Enseñanza de Girona; the establishment allowed pursuing religious path but offered also commercial studies.<ref>''Bulleti del Santuari S. María del Collel'' 7 (1917), available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/pdf.raw?query=id:0000181678&page=16 here]</ref> In 1887 he obtained bachillerato, officially issued by Instituto de Girona,<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, pp. 54-5</ref> and enrolled at Facultad de Filosofía y Letras in the University of Barcelona. Llosas graduated in 1890, his dissertation dedicated to the [[Tiberius Gracchus|Gracchus]] land reforms in the [[ancient Rome]] and acknowledged with excellent marks.<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 54</ref> He pursued scientific path later on, already when he served as deputy in [[Madrid]]; in 1915 he graduated in Madrid in history,<ref>some scholars suspect he might have intended to obtain PhD laurels, Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 54</ref> his thesis titled ''Renaixement de Catalunya, època del rei Martí l'Humà'';<ref>''El Deber'' 04.12.15, referred after ''¡Arriba España!'' 04.12.65, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000287197&page=5 here]</ref> also later he remained particularly interested in [[archeology]].<ref>„aficionat a l’arqueologia”, Josep Burch i Rius et al. (eds.), ''Emili Gandia i la conservació del patrimoni cultural a la Catalunya de començament del segle XX'', Girona 2015, {{ISBN|9788499843018}}, page unavailable, accessible [https://books.google.es/books?id=nMqZCwAAQBAJ&pg=PP45 here]</ref> One source refers to him as „abogado”.<ref>Artagan 1912, p. 236; no information on his would-have-been law studies is available elsewhere</ref> [[File:Vayreda6.JPG|thumbnail|160px|''[[:ca:El combregar a muntanya|Viático]]'' by [[Marian Vayreda i Vila|Vayreda]]]] Having returned to Olot in 1893 Llosas Badía married Anna Serat-Calvó y Plana (died 1942);<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 54, ''La Vanguardia'' 14.03.42, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1929/05/15/pagina-3/33110547/pdf.html here]; also [[FamilySearch]], "España, matrimonios, 1565-1950," database, available [https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:FFFB-3NQ here]</ref> they settled at calle de San Jerónimo 47.<ref>''Guía Oficial de España'' 1911, p. 61, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001003698&page=61 here]; later they moved to calle Fontanella, ''¡Arriba España!'' 03.12.55, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000277710&page=10 here]; the couple also possessed an estate in neighboring Santa Pau, ''Tradició Catalana'' 12.08.33, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000257225&page=24 here]</ref> In 1895 he and two relatives founded a local bank, Banco Llosas, Escubós y Puigmitjà,<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 55</ref> which proved successful and remained their property until the mid-1920s.<ref>the bank served both local aristocrats like [[:es:Marquesado de Monistrol de Noya|marqués de Monistrol]] and local companies, like Sangrà i Cia, Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 55; apart from the local provincial market it was also engaged in some nationwide schemes like hydrotechnical works on the Guadalquivir, see ''ABC'' 06.06.15, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1915/06/06/006.html here], and was first one in Girona province to introduce safe deposits, Ramón Llongarriu i Monsalvatje, ''La banca a Olot'', [in:] ''bohigas'' service, available [http://www.bohigas.com/Exposici/Montsalv/AP0306.htm here]</ref> Pedro and Anna had 6 children, born between 1894 and 1904, but the family life was marked by recurring tragedies: María died in early infancy, Rosa - who married Joaquin Vayreda Aulet, son the Olot [[Traditionalism (Spain)|Traditionalist]] painter and author, [[Marian Vayreda i Vila|Marian Vayreda]]<ref>the wedding took place in 1917, ''Comarca'' 12.05.17, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000187061&page=7 here], see also ''La Vanguardia'' 03.01.69, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1969/01/03/pagina-28/33568941/pdf.html here]; Rosa Llosas probably died when giving birth a year later, ''La Comarca'' 01.06.18, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000187762&page=10 here]</ref> - died at 23 in 1918,<ref>''El Deber'' 01.06.18, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000161302&page=19 here]</ref> Nonito died also at 23 in 1921<ref>''Tradició Catalana'' 22.07.22, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000242261&page=23 here]</ref> and Juan died at 41 in 1933.<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 16.02.33, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1928/10/05/pagina-17/33173968/pdf.html here]</ref> Of the two surviving, Martirián Llosas y Serrat-Calvó - also a Carlist<ref>in the late 1940s and the early 1950s he was member of Junta Regional, the Catalan Carlist executive, César Alcalá, ''D. Mauricio de Sivatte. Una biografía política (1901-1980),'' Barcelona 2001, {{ISBN|8493109797}}, pp. 95, 99</ref> - was active in the [[Barcelona]] juvenile court, during early [[Francoism]] serving briefly as president of the Gerona diputacion<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 16.08.39, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1929/05/15/pagina-9/33120093/pdf.html here]</ref> and rising to president judge of Tribunal Tutelar de Menores de Barcelona and president of Union Nacional de Tribunales Tutelares de Menores,<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 14.06.69, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/2007/11/08/pagina-29/33590021/pdf.html here]</ref> apart from having been president of Obra Tutelar Agraria for 27 years.<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 22.10.85, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/2007/11/08/pagina-28/32865260/pdf.html here]</ref> Miguel Llosas y Serrat-Calvó pursued a law career<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 09.12.28, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1928/12/09/pagina-28/33216649/pdf.html here]</ref> and was also active as judge for the minors,<ref>Santiago Olives Canals, Stephen Taylor, ''Who's who in Spain'' vol. 1, Madrid 1963, p. 508</ref> but became a public figure mostly as a man of letters.<ref>compare his works at ''Biblioteca de Catalunya'' service, available [http://cataleg.bnc.cat:2082/search*cat/X?SEARCH=(Llosas)&SORT=DX here]</ref> Apart from lesser works on history<ref>e.g. ''Besalú al setge d'Almenara'', [in:] ''Assemblees d'estudis Besalú'' 1 (1968), pp. 91-98 or ''El comte Tallaferro a Còrdova'', [in:] ''Assemblees d'estudis Besalú'' 2 (1973), pp. 183-200</ref> and culture;<ref>e.g. ''El arte moderno en su proyección religiosa'', [in:] ''Cristianidad'' 17 (1960), pp. 26-29</ref> his major study focusing on ancient Rome, ''Berenice'', was published posthumously.<ref>Miguel Llosas y Serrat-Calvó, ''Berenice'', Girona 2007, {{ISBN|9788496766075}}</ref>
==Carlist== [[File:Benedicció de la bandera del Somatent al Passeig del Firal d'Olot.jpg|thumbnail|160px|left|Llosas in [[Olot]], 1911]] In the late 19th century Olot was among Catalan Carlist strongholds. Painting activity of [[Olot school|Escuela de Olot]] and literary works of Marian Vayreda y Vila made it cultural centre of regional Traditionalism and conservative Catalanism.<ref>there is massive literature on Vayreda, covering his paintings, his literary works, his political activity and his ideology; on the latter, see e.g. Rafael Botella García-Lastra, ''El carlismo en la novela'', [in:] Miguel Ayuso (ed.), ''A los 175 años del carlismo'', Madrid, 2011, {{ISBN|978-8493678777}}, pp. 401–434 Narcís Selles, ''Entre un món residual i un món emergent'', [in:] ''Esposició antologica de Marian Vayreda i Vila (1853 - 1903)'', Olot 2003, pp. 25–31, Narcís Selles, ''Marian Vayreda: idealització i conflicte davant d'una realitat canviant'', [in:] ''Revista de Girona'' 220 (2003), pp. 30–35, Edgar Illas, ''Marià Vayreda. El carlisme reciclat i l'inconscient català'', [in:] ''El contemporani: revista d'història'' 27 (2003), pp. 48–51, Francesc Roma, ''Del Paradís a la Nació: la muntanya a Catalunya, segles XV-XX'', Valls 2004, {{ISBN|8497910818}} and works of Jordi Canal, quoted later</ref> The young Pedro – though nothing is known about political preferences of his ancestors – was growing exposed to both and actively engaged in both.<ref>on complex relationship between Carlism and Catalanism see detailed discussion in Jordi Canal, ''Carlisme i catalanisme a la fi del segle XIX. Notes sobre unes relacions complexes'', [in:] ''Le discours sur la nation en Catalogne aux XIXe et XXe siècles. Hommage à Antoni M. Badia i Margarit'', Paris 1995, pp. 211–230, Jordi Canal, ''¿En busca del precedente perdido? Tríptico sobre las complejas relaciones entre carlismo y catalanismo a fines del siglo XIX'', [in:] ''Historia y Politica'' 14 (2005), pp. 45-84, Jordi Canal, ''Marian Vayreda, entre el carlisme i el catalánisme'', [in:] ''Revista de Girona'' 225 (2004), pp. 41–46</ref> In 1891 he was already reported as secretary of the local Centre Catalanista,<ref>''L’Oloti'' 09.08.91, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000219949&page=9 here]</ref> 1892 growing to its vice-president;<ref>''L’Oloti'' 10.01.92, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000220248&page=10 here]</ref> during his early years he also entered the local Circulo Tradicionalista,<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, pp. 54-5</ref> at unspecified date rising to its president.<ref>Artagan 1912, p. 236</ref> In the mid-1890s Llosas was also busy in local Olotense and regional Catalan Catholic initiatives.<ref>''Eco de la montaña'' 12.08.94, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000132842&page=1 here]</ref> Apart from organizational work he was active as a speaker<ref>Artagan 1912, p. 236</ref> and especially as an author, contributing to periodicals like ''L’Olotí'' and ''El Deber'', though also ''Diario de Olot''<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 55</ref> and ''El Ateneo'';<ref>''Revista del Ateneo Obrero de Olot'', 01.03.08, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000135646&page=7 here]</ref> his writings revealed a knack for culture and history.<ref>''Album literati y artístich de l’Oloti'' 1 (1894), available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000287324&page=2 here]</ref> Known locally, until the early 20th century Llosas did not emerge as a recognized figure in Catalan Carlism.<ref>Llosas is not listed a single time in a monographic work on Catalan Carlism of the late 19th century, see Jordi Canal, ''El carlisme català dins l’Espanya de la Restauració. Un assaig de modernizació política (1888-1900)'', Vic 1998, {{ISBN|8476022433}}</ref>
In 1897 Llosas was elected to the Olot [[ayuntamiento]],<ref>Artagan 1912, p. 236, also ''Deber'' 15.05.97, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000136733&page=12 here]</ref> becoming the third teniente de alcalde,<ref>''Annuario-Riera'' 1899, p. 931, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0004970926&page=931 here]</ref> president of Comisión de Gobernación and member of the other two.<ref>Comisión Central and Comisión de Hospital, Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 56</ref> During the following term<ref>which commenced in 1899</ref> he grew to the first [[Deputy mayor|teniente de alcalde]], president of Comisión de Fomento and vocal of the central, hospital<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 56</ref> and economy<ref>''Annuario-Riera'' 1904, p. 1604, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0005045954&page=1604 here]</ref> commissions, in 1900 briefly serving as [[alcalde]].<ref>following health problems of the mayor himself, ''Sanch Nova'' 30.12.00, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000238117&page=18 here]</ref> In 1903 Llosas presented his candidature to the [[:ca:Diputació de Girona|provincial self-government of Girona]]; he stood as a "regionalista".<ref>''Montanyench'' 15.03.03, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000217274&page=2 here]</ref> Elected from the Olot-Puigcerda district, he served as diputado until 1907.<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 56; he was one of 14 deputies to Girona provincial self-government and one of 51 deputies in all 4 Catalan provinces between 1900 and 1923, Molas 2009, pp. 22-3</ref> In the provincial self-government he represented a Traditionalist version of regionalism, declaring himself a Catalanist and anti-centralist;<ref>''La Información'' 22.09.04</ref> his opening address in the chamber was in [[Catalan language|Catalan]], an extravaganza which earned him admonition by the president.<ref>i. e. José Puig y Corominola, Costa Fernández 1994, p. 286</ref> As member of diputación he inspired and supported a new Olot Traditionalist periodical, ''La Tradició Catalana''.<ref>Costa Fernández 1994, p. 416</ref> At that time he also published pamphlets formatted as discourses on political philosophy.<ref>''Veritable concepte de la democràcia cristiana'' (1902), ''Concepte filosòfich-social de la tradicìò: discurs llegit per son autor en la solemne sessió literària-musical celebrada baix la presidencia del Exm. Sr. Bisbe de Vich, Dr. Joseph Torras y Bages'' (1903)</ref> [[File:Caricatura anticarlina a L'Esquella de la Torratxa el 1914.jpg|thumbnail|200px|''ridícol jaumista'', 1914]] In mid-1900s Llosas decided to run for the [[Cortes Generales|Cortes]]. The Olot district voted Carlists in the late 19th century,<ref>in 1896 and 1898 Olot elected a former Carlist military, [[Joaquín Lloréns Fernández de Cordoba|Joaquín Llorens]], see the official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXLDA.fmt&DOCS=1-25&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&QUERY=%2861480%29.NDIP. here]</ref> but in the 1899-1907 it was conquered by [[Lliga Regionalista|La Lliga]].<ref>Albert Balcells, Joan B. Culla, Conxita Mir, ''Les eleccions generals a Catalunya de 1901 a 1923'', Barcelona 1982, p. 430</ref> The two competing groupings joined ranks [[Spanish general election, 1907|in 1907]], together with the [[Republicanism in Spain|Republicans]] forming [[:ca:Solidaritat Catalana|Solidaritat Catalana]].<ref>the alliance was united mostly by opposition to the so-called Ley de Jurisdicciones; for detailed discussion, see Maria Gemma Rubí i Casals, Francesc Espinet, ''Solidaritat catalana i Espanya (1905-1909)'', Barcelona 2008, {{ISBN|9788492437153}}</ref> Though some solidaris accepted Llosas with difficulty,<ref>Balcells, Culla, Mir 1982, p. 127</ref> the strategy paid off; he was among seven Carlists voted in from Catalonia.<ref>he obtained 54,79% of the votes and his independent counter-candidate 44,39% (abstention 24,66%), Balcells, Culla, Mir 1982, p.523; see also the official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=1-1&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2861630%29.NDIP. here]</ref> The alliance soon disintegrated, but also in the following years La Lliga and the Carlists avoided fielding candidates in the same districts; as Olot was left to the Carlists,<ref>Balcells, Culla, Mir 1982, pp. 204, 221, 227</ref> Llosas retained his mandate in successive campaigns of [[Spanish general election, 1910|1910]],<ref>he obtained 85,93% of the votes and his mearest counter-candidate, a republican radical, 11,97% (abstention 24,63%), Balcells, Culla, Mir 1982, p.534, see also the official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=2-2&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2861630%29.NDIP. here]</ref> [[Spanish general election, 1914|1914]]<ref>he obtained 80,83% of the votes and his mearest counter-candidate, a republican , 15,14% (abstention 27,53%), Balcells, Culla, Mir 1982, p.547, see also the official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=3-3&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2861630%29.NDIP. here]</ref> (when he ran as independent)<ref>Balcells, Culla, Mir 1982, p. 198; his victory was overwhelming and the scale of opposition posed by his republican opponent is named „symbolic”, Balcells, Culla, Mir 1982, p. 204</ref> and [[Spanish general election, 1916|1916]] (declared victorious with no challenger),<ref>Balcells, Culla, Mir 1982, p. 227, see also the official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=4-4&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2861630%29.NDIP. here]</ref> having been member of a small, depending upon term 6 to 14-member Carlist minority. His parliamentarian activity – vibrant especially during earlier terms<ref>e.g. in 1907 he spoke 20 times, Artagan 1912, p. 236</ref> - was marked mostly by defense of Catholic Church<ref>in recognition of his merits, in 1914 he was awarded Pro Ecclesia et Pontífice, a papal medal conferred upon those distinguished in their service to the Church, Moret i Llosas 1994, pp. 58-9</ref> and by his modest Catalanism,<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, pp. 56-7</ref> culminating in confronting the government sponsored [[:es:Ley del Candado|Ley del Candado]].<ref>compare ''El Kulturkamf Español. Primera Etapa. La Ley llamada del Candado y la oposición católica en las Cortes. Colección de discursos pronunciados por los Reverendos Prelados y por los representantes de las Minorías tradicionalistas'', Madrid 1915</ref> He was counted among representatives of Catalan "carlisme nou";<ref>with Junyent, Argemí, Trías and Iglesias, i.e. militants who did not remember the Third Carlist War and grew during Restoration, Molas 2009, p. 14</ref> in 1912 he entered the Carlist national executive.<ref>named Junta Superior Central; all Carlist parliamentarians entered the body by default; within the body Llosas was appointed to Comisión de Acción Social in 1913, see [[Melchor Ferrer Dalmau|Melchor Ferrer]], ''Breve historia del legitimismo español'', Madrid 1958, p. 97, Agustín Fernández Escudero, ''El marqués de Cerralbo (1845-1922): biografía politica'' [PhD thesis UNED], Madrid 2012, pp. 445, 458</ref>
==Bewildered== [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|thumbnail|left|Carlist standard]] In the late 1910s the Catalan Carlism was undergoing rapid fragmentation, marked by at least three not necessarily overlapping division lines: between supporters of the key party theorist [[Juan Vázquez de Mella|Vázquez de Mella]] versus supporters of the [[Jaime, Duke of Madrid|claimant]], between those approaching nascent Catalanism with sympathy versus those viewing it with caution, and between a faction favoring wide conservative alliances versus a faction sticking to stand-alone intransigence.<ref>other division lines were between Carlists who viewed their movement as „party of order” versus young urban militants with penchant for violence, see Colin M. Winston, ''Workers and the Right in Spain, 1900-1936, Princeton 2014'', {{ISBN|9781400858095}}, p. 85, and differences over personal issues, e.g. in case of Llerida province, see Conxita Mir, ''Lleida (1890-1936): caciquisme polític i lluita electoral'', Barcelona 1985, {{ISBN|9788472027169}}, pp. 308-310</ref> Though a 1912 Carlist propaganda publication hailed his „acrisolada lealtad a los ideales Católico-Monárquicos”,<ref>Artagan 1912, p. 237</ref> Llosas was not immune to growing confusion.
In Girona the key division line was about the Catalan question.<ref>some areas of the Olot district adopted "un posicionament proper al regionalisme i encetaren un acostament a la Lliga", while in the Girona generally the mood was rather against the Catalanists, Costa Fernández 1994, pp. 32-3</ref> Llosas, unlike other key Carlist from the province [[Dalmacio Iglesias García|Dalmacio Iglesias]], tended to demonstrate more attraction for Catalanism than the official party executive would allow. In 1917 he took part in [[:es:Asamblea de Parlamentarios|Parliamentary Assembly]], a gathering of some 70 senators and deputies mostly from Catalonia.<ref>''El Pais'' 08.07.17, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002539658&page=1 here]</ref> Called in the wake of growing social tension, the congregation declared the Restoration political system defunct and assumed a potentially revolutionary shape, pursuing also a highly regionalist model of state.<ref>Llosas and others were "baluarte monarquico ante las amenazas militares y civiles"; some sources claimed that Llosas himself co-drafted an autonomy proposal, later supported by the regionalists and others, Maximiliano Fuentes Codera, ''España en la Primera Guerra Mundial: Una movilización cultural'', Madrid 2014, {{ISBN|9788446040262}}, page unavailable, accessible [https://books.google.ru/books?id=4rsABAAAQBAJ&pg=PT162 here]</ref> Since the Carlists decided to abstain, Llosas joined the initiative on his own; some authors claim that he broke with the party,<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 57</ref> but others underline that proposals of the Assembly were later supported by the Carlists.<ref>other authors claim the autonomist proposals of the assembly were supported by the Jaimists, see Fuentes Codera 2014</ref>
The [[Spanish general election, 1918|1918 electoral campaign]] produced total bewilderment. Despite Llosas’ taking part in the pro-Catalanist Assembly, La Lliga terminated the truce with the Carlists and fielded his counter-candidate in Olot. The Carlists themselves were divided into 3 factions led by [[:es:Miguel Junyent|Junyent]], Iglesias and Llosas, the latter turned against La Lliga running as an ultra-Right anti-regionalist hopeful.<ref>Junyent concluded alliances with La Lliga and the Maurists, while Llosas, Iglesias and Trias were presenting themselves as ultra-Right anti-regionalists candidates, supported by the anti-regionalist ''El Norte'', Xavier Tornafoch, ''Política, eleccions i caciquisme a Vic'' [PhD thesis Universitat Autonoma de Barcelona], Barcelona 2003, p. 199, also Costa Fernández 1994 p. 34, Balcells, Culla, Mir 1982, pp. 249, 256, 263</ref> Despite his differences with party executive, he was widely referred to as "carlí", "jaumí"<ref>Balcells, Culla, Mir 1982, pp. 256, 571, also ''ABC'' 25.02.18, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1918/02/25/010.html here], ''El Sol'' 12.02.18, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000184647&page=4 here]</ref> or "tradicionalista".<ref>Albert Balcells, Enric Pujol, Jordi Sabater, ''La Mancomunitat de Catalunya i L'Autonomia'', Barcelona 1996, {{ISBN|9788472833296}} p. 247</ref> By a narrow margin he seemed to have lost to his Lliguero rival.<ref>having gained 45,37% of the votes; his victorious counter-candidate, a Lliguero candidate, obtained 53,97% of the votes (abstention 16,99%), Balcells, Culla, Mir 1982, p.571. In the early campaigns, when in open accord with La Lliga, Llosas enjoyed absolute majority among the electorate, but over time his domination decreased. In 1907 he was supported by 75% of those eligible to vote, in 1910 by 65%, in 1914 by 37%. For 1916 - as he had no counter-candidate - no number-crunching is possible. In 1918 he was supported by 38% of the electorate, but his Lliguero rival attracted 45% of those eligible, data Balcells, Culla, Mir 1982</ref> He protested, pressing charges of corruption; investigations and backstage haggling continued until he was finally declared defeated.<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 57</ref> [[File:HUU.12.21.12.jpg|thumbnail|Llosas with bishops, Colegio de Santa María del Collell, 1919]] When the internal Carlist conflict between de Mella and [[Jaime, Duke of Madrid|Don Jaime]] exploded in 1919 Llosas seemed posed to join the [[Mellismo|rebels]]. In the Cortes under the influence of the former<ref>in 1912 formed part of grupo parlamentario africanista, co-led by Vázquez de Mella. ''El Siglo Futuro'' 24.12.12, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000309817&page=3 here]</ref> and sharing his penchant for grand conservative alliances,<ref>Molas 2009, p. 9</ref> initially he tended to stand against the claimant.<ref>in Catalonia Carlism fragmented into 3 groupings: firstly the majoritarian one headed by Junyent, Trias and Roma, organized around Correo Catalan, pro-League and loyal to Don Jaime; secondly the minoritarian one led by Pedro Vives and centred around Ateneu Tradicionalista and thirdly another one, led by Dalmacio Iglesias and dominating in Girona province, the latter ones sided with the Mellistas, Balcells, Culla, Mir 1982, p. 285</ref> Eventually he declared himself neutral;<ref>Molas 2009, p. 10; the provincial Girona jefatura of the Mellistas went to Joaquim de Solà Morales</ref> indeed, after the breakup he was listed neither among the breakaway Mellistas<ref>Llosas is not a single time mentioned in scholarly monograph on the Mellista movement, see Juan Ramón de Andrés Martín, ''El cisma mellista. Historia de una ambición política'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|9788487863820}}</ref> nor the loyal Jaimistas. Instead, he neared the right wing of disintegrating [[Conservative Party (Spain)|Conservatives]], the [[Antonio Maura|Mauristas]];<ref>Molas 2009, p. 10</ref> in the [[Spanish general election, 1919|1919 electoral campaign]] he unsuccessfully ran for the [[Senate (Spain)|Senate]] as a governmental candidate,<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 07.06.19, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000363280&page=3 here], ''El Pais'' 14.06.19, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002572909&page=3 here]</ref> defeated for the upper chamber also in [[Spanish general election, 1920|1921]] with only 16% of the votes gathered;<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 57</ref> some kept referring to him as "jaimista".<ref>''El Sol'' 14.06.19, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000210440&page=3 here]</ref>
Llosas’s affair with the Mauristas continued; in October 1921 Maura, prime minister at that time, appointed him [[:es:Gobernador civil|civil governor]] of the [[Baleares (province)|Balearic Islands]]. Little is known about his tenure; according to present-day scholar, he demonstrated rather heavy hand and acted along "lógica dins un sistema caciquista basat en la venjanca",<ref>Isabel Peñarrubia i Marquès, ''Els partits polítics davant el caciquisme i la qüestió nacional a Mallorca (1917-1923)'', Barcelona 1991, {{ISBN|9788478262724}}, p. 109</ref> having been firm element of the [[:es:Caciquismo (España)|caciquismo]] structure.<ref>Peñarrubia i Marquès 1991, p. 59</ref> For reasons which are not clear he resigned from the governor post in April 1922 and returned to Olot.<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 57</ref>
==''Primoderiverista''== [[File:Homenaje-tumba-Rafael-Casanova-San-Baudilio-Mancomunidad-Cataluña-1922.jpg|thumbnail|180px|left|[[Commonwealth of Catalonia|Mancomunitat]], 1920s]] Llosas welcomed the 1923 coup of general [[Miguel Primo de Rivera|Primo de Rivera]] and already in 1924 he was busy setting up provincial structures of nascent [[Patriotic Union (Spain)|Unión Patriótica]]; he emerged heading the Olot branch,<ref>Costa Fernández 1994, p. 210</ref> though he did not enter the provincial Girona executive.<ref>Costa Fernández 1994, p. 208</ref> Also 1924 he was nominated to two Catalan self-government bodies, provincial and regional ones, normally elected but its members appointed under the new dictatorial regime. One was Diputación Provincial of Girona,<ref>Costa Fernández 1994, pp. 185-6</ref> whose members elected him president of the body.<ref>with 18 votes in favor and 1 abstaining, Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 57</ref> Another was Permanent Council of [[Commonwealth of Catalonia|Mancomunitat de Catalunya]];<ref>Costa Fernández 1994, p. 189</ref> he briefly served as Conseller de Ferrocarrils i Obres Hidràuliques and member of Consell de Pedagogia, before becoming member of Consell de Cultura.<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 57</ref> At the latter post he shielded [[Institut d'Estudis Catalans]] from growing [[Spanish nationalism|españolismo]],<ref>viewed with sincere hostility by the government, Costa Fernández 1994, p. 285. Llosas vehemently opposed attempts to merge the Institute with the University, Costa Fernández 1994, p. 287-8; he also helped to develop new activities of the Institute, like library, meteorological, historic-archeologic and especially philology services, establishing as a newly created section, „Servicio de Investigaciones Filológicas” - Costa Fernández 1994, pp. 286-9</ref> advocated introduction of Catalan to schools<ref>Costa Fernández 1994, pp. 285-6</ref> and developed local libraries.<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 24.10.24, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1935/02/21/pagina-6/33269071/pdf.html here]</ref>
In 1924 the Girona diputación addressed Primo with a Llosas-inspired document, which opposed centralization designs of Catalan capitán [[:es:Emilio Barrera|general Barrera]]<ref>other author claims that Llosas was not in favor of abolishing Mancomunitat, Costa Fernández 1994, p. 196</ref> and advanced a highly regionalist vision of state in general and Catalonia in particular.<ref>"posicionament regionalista de Llosas", Costa Fernández 1994, p. 191</ref> The paper proposed a province-centred organization of Catalonia modeled on the [[Names of the Basque Country (in Spanish)|Vascongadas]].<ref>"amb una actitud propera a la manifestada antigament per carlins i jaumins, que propagaven una solució semblant a les diputacions basques, és a dir, implantar el régim provincial de les provincies bascongades", Costa Fernández 1994, p. 196; opposing centralist views were sponsored presided by general Barrera and Frederic Bassols</ref> It suggested that on the regional level Mancomunitat, itself deemed artificial, is replaced by a new body, Diputación Regional, its members delegated from provincial chambers, themselves elected on universal, corporative and municipal basis.<ref>Costa Fernández 1994, pp. 191-2</ref> However, the new [[:es:Estatuto Provincial de 1925|primoderiverista Estatuto Provincial]] potentially led to dissolution of regional bodies;<ref>the new Provincial Stature it did not necessarily mean dissolving Mancomunitat, Costa Fernández 1994, p. 197</ref> anxious to retain some regional co-ordination,<ref>Costa Fernández 1994, pp. 198-9; Llosas was anxious that lack of regional coordination would produce a downturn in some areas, especially public works, Costa Fernández 1994, p. 197</ref> Llosas failed to convince other members of the Girona diputation,<ref>bowing to the pressure of provincial civil governor Urquía</ref> who effectively buried the idea of Mancomunitat.<ref>Costa Fernández 1994, p. 11</ref> Acknowledging defeat Llosas resigned as head of Girona self-government.<ref>some refer to the event as „fi de la carrera política de Llosas a Girona”. Costa Fernández 1994, p. 197</ref> Nevertheless, he took part in works of Comissió Gestora entrusted with phasing out Mancomunitat until the body ceased to exist in 1925.<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 58</ref> {{CSS image crop |Image = Boletin de pescas (1921) (20379351572).jpg |bSize = 500 |cWidth = 220 |cHeight = 160 |oTop = 20 |oLeft = 20 |Location = right |Description = Palma de Mallorca, 1920s }}
Despite differences with the military, Llosas by no means could have been considered in opposition to Primo;<ref>„vinculat al poder de Madrid”, Jordi Pujiula, ''Dictadura, República i Guerra Civil'', Olot 2005, {{ISBN|9788493262457}}, pp. 13</ref> his stance during tenure in Diputación Provincial and Mancomunitat should rather be viewed as efforts to find a compromise within framework of the regime. On good terms with the dictator, in May 1925 he was appointed civil governor of La Coruña province.<ref>''El Imparcial'' 21.05.25, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000963339&page=5 here]</ref> Apart from standard administrative activities<ref>see ''La Nación'' 09.02.26, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0026219478&page=8 here]</ref> he again pursued a heavy-handed political line;<ref>e.g. banning a conference declared as scientific but suspected of pursuing a hidden political agenda, Costa Fernández 1994, p. 197</ref> aligned with the government, he cared little about the local opinion,<ref>Costa Fernández 1994, p. 289</ref> though some refer to him as a pragmatist.<ref>Costa Fernández 1994, p. 290</ref> Quoting health reasons and issuing an ambiguous farewell statement,<ref>"declara sinceramente que, identificado con el generoso sentir y las costumbres de Galicia, no le ha sido difícil fundar sus normas de gobierno "en una base de realidad eterminada por múltiples semejanzas y analogías y en la adopción de medidas de leal advertencia y suave persuasión antes dc recurrir a procedimientos coercitivos, ingratos de suyo, aunque saludables y necesarios en ciertos casos", ''La Nación'' 03.05.26, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0026221612&page=18 here].</ref> he resigned in April 1926.<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 58</ref> The same year he was transferred to the parallel post in the Balearic Islands, commencing a second string in [[Palma de Mallorca, Balearic Islands|Palma]].<ref>''Heraldo de Madrid'' 28.04.26, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000837817&page=3 here]</ref> Little is known about his tenure. Press of the era provided only official information about cultural activities,<ref>e.g. setting up Museo Pedagógico Provincional, ''La Nación'' 25.12.28, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0026259481&page=6 here]</ref> diplomatic routine,<ref>he received the Italian Ordine dei Santi Maurizio e Lazzaro, bestowed upon him by Mussolini in 1929; the honor seemed fairly routine, result of Italian military aircraft squadron landing at the Baleares during a courtesy visit, Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 59</ref> construction of public utility establishments,<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 26.07.28, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1928/09/11/pagina-14/33200425/pdf.html here], ''La Vanguardia'' 14.09.27, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1927/11/11/pagina-18/33240355/pdf.html here]</ref> propaganda,<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 10.07.28, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1928/09/11/pagina-29/33208288/pdf.html here]</ref> building new railway lines<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 10.07.29, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1929/09/18/pagina-21/33237322/pdf.html herel]</ref> etc., though there were single complaints about his uncompromising stand recorded.<ref>Jaume Pomar, ''La raó i el meu dret: biografia de Llorenç Villalonga'', Palma de Mallorca 1995, {{ISBN|9788427340381}}, p. 123</ref> Upon resignation of Primo in 1930 Llosas put himself at disposal of the new [[Dámaso Berenguer|Berenguer]] government and was not re-appointed.<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 58</ref> He settled back in Olot,<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 21.02.30, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1928/07/26/pagina-26/33217493/pdf.html here]</ref> dedicating himself to family<ref>his oldest son died in 1933 in his early 40s, ''La Vanguardia'' 10.02.33, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1933/11/09/pagina-27/33173318/pdf.html here]</ref> and business.<ref>his private archive contains politically relevant documents dated prior to 1930 only, Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 61</ref>
==Retiree: Republic and Francoism== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 102-11543, Madrid, Ausrufung der Zweiten Spanischen Republik.jpg|thumbnail|left|Catalonia: [[Second Spanish Republic|Republic]] declared, 1931]] Llosas enjoyed excellent financial standing; apart from family properties, he held managerial posts in the Olot branch of [[:es:Banco Hispano Americano|Banco Hispano Americano]],<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 55. In the 1920s the Spanish financial market was subject to consolidation, with 5 major banks dominating the industry - Banco Hispano Americano, Banco Español de Credito, Banco Central, Banco de Bilbao and Banco de Vizcaya, Moisés Llordén Miñambres, Manuel-Jesús González, ''De empresas y empresarios en la España contemporanea'', Oviedo 1995, {{ISBN|9788474688191}}, p. 96. One of the most aggressive players, Banco Hispano Americano, pursued a growth strategy consisting of taking over smalle banks and convering them into own branches – from 6 (1914) to 20 (1919), 50 (1923) and 87 (1926) Llordén, González 1995, p. 96</ref> the giant which took over Banco Llosas Escubós in the mid-1920s;<ref>BHE entered merger talks with Banco Llosas Escubós in 1920 Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 55, also ''El Financiero'' 20.08.20, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0025435348&page=6 here], completing the process in 1923, Muñoz García Muñoz, ''El Fracaso de la Burguesía Financiera Catalana: La Crisis Del Banco de Barcelona'', Barcelona 1988, {{ISBN|9788477310099}}, p. 308; Llosas grew also to vice-president of Asociación de Banqueros de Barcelona - Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 56</ref> he was referred to as "banquer",<ref>Molas 2009, p. 19, Balcells, Culla, Mir 1982, p. 430, also "ex-banquer", Costa Fernández 1994, pp. 185-6</ref> "propietario",<ref>Molas 2009, p. 13, Balcells, Culla, Mir 1982, p. 430</ref> "comerciante" and "haciendista".<ref>Artagan 1912, p. 237</ref> He basked in prestige of key Girona politician,<ref>Pujiula 2005, pp. 13, 22, 185</ref> a charismatic figure<ref>Costa Fernández 1994, p. 420</ref> and local patricio, his house continuously visited by applicants seeking support.<ref>for a picturesque account see ''¡Arriba España''! 03.04.48, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000273326&page=2 here]</ref> Llosas’ position changed dramatically upon advent of the [[Second Spanish Republic|Republic]]: as a former dictatorship tycoon, a monarchist and a Traditionalist reactionary he found himself politically sidetracked. A street in Santa Pau, named after him in 1930,<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 01.05.30, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1929/05/15/pagina-6/33217585/pdf.html here]</ref> was immediately renamed to Via de la República in 1931.<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 26.09.31, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1933/11/09/pagina-21/33174239/pdf.html here]; the street was restored as Calle Pedro Llosas in the Francoist era, ''Revista de Girona'' 01.01.70, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000490788&page=22 here]. Currently it is named Avenida Olot – Bañolas, Salvador Reixach, ''Santa Pau'', Girona 1998, {{ISBN|8486812917}}, p, 63, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000365431&page=63 here]</ref>
Llosas focused on religious activity: in the early 1930s he took part in Catholic initiatives like Pro Ecclesia et Patria weeks, contributed to confessional periodicals<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 21.02.35, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1935/02/21/pagina-17/33141889/pdf.html here], ''La Vanguardia'' 26.09.34, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1928/07/26/pagina-17/33153563/pdf.html here], ''La Vanguardia'' 05.10.34, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1928/07/26/pagina-20/33154812/pdf.html here]</ref> and in 1933 led a large group of Catalans visiting [[Vatican City|Vatican]].<ref>''ABC'' 13.09.33, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1933/09/13/029.html here]</ref> He resumed contacts with Carlism.<ref>which renewed as Comunión Tradicionalista re-admitted also the former primoderiverista officials. Llosas was not listed as member of Junta Provincial de Girona, Josep Clara, ''La Comunió Tradicionalista a Girona (1931-1936)'', [in:] ''El Carlisme entra Dues Guerres, 1876-1936, Revista de Girona'' 1991, p. 84-5. He is known to have supported the Carlist daily ''El Siglo Futuro'' financially, see ''El Siglo Futuro'' 21.12.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000569038&page=7 here]. Some authors claim that Llosas stance during the dictatorship contributed to demise of Carlism in the province, which at the advent of the Republic was in "punt més baix de la seva história, com una relíquia del passat" and looked dead - "també semhiaven morís, pero no pas enterráis, els carlins. Pocs i mal avinguts. resten un poc pertot i especialment a la Garrotxa, alguns contumacos que no s'acaben de decidirá desaparéixer. A la capilal, una dotzena mal comptada completa aquesta fauna que sembla destinada a esvair-se en un futur molt próxim", Clara 1991, p. 83</ref> During run-up to the [[Spanish general election, 1933|1933 electoral campaign]] he was initially reported as standing in candidatura de derecha agraría, neighboring with frontline Carlist activists like [[María Rosa Urraca Pastor|Urraca Pastor]] and defined as "tradicionalista";<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 09.11.33, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1929/05/15/pagina-19/33188294/pdf.html here]</ref> eventually he declared the news not authorized.<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 11.11.33, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1933/11/09/pagina-17/33188360/pdf.html here]</ref> He kept supplying historical and religious articles to Traditionalist periodicals.<ref>in Catalan, e.g. ''A proposit de les festes de Corpus'', published in'' Tradició Catalana'' 02.06.34, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000258535&page=7 here]; Llosas kept pursuing his historical and archeological interest throughout all his life, publishing also in the 1910s and 1920s, see booklets ''Olot en temps d’Alfons V el Mangánim'' (1913), ''La Reyna Empordanesa. D Sibila de Fortcá'' (1923), ''Jaime I el Conquistador'' (1929), and articles, e.g. ''El diplomatari del Comitat del Besalú'', [in:]'' Renovació: fulles populars de la Joventut Nacionalista'' 31.01.18, pp. 61-64, ''Viva nueva... resurrección'', [in:] ''Vida Parroquial'' 2 (1929), pp. 3-7</ref> In early 1936 Llosas together with other Catalan Carlists<ref>like Miguel Junyent, [[Joaquín Bau]], [[:es:Bartolomé Trías|Bartolomé Trias]] or Luis Argemi</ref> took part in broad monarchist gatherings led by [[Calvo Sotelo]],<ref>''Correo de Tortosa'' 21.01.36</ref> though his relations with Carlism remained loose.<ref>Llosas is not a single time mentioned either in history of Carlism during the Republic in Spain, see Martin Blinkhorn, ''Carlism and Crisis in Spain 1931-1939'', Cambridge 2008, {{ISBN|9780521207294}}, or in Catalonia, see Robert Vallverdú i Martí, ''El Carlisme Català Durant La Segona República Espanyola 1931-1936'', Barcelona 2008, {{ISBN|9788478260805}}</ref>
Llosas welcomed the [[Spanish coup of July 1936|coup of July 1936]] though there is no information on him having been involved.<ref>Moret i Llosas 1994, p. 58</ref> Following the [[Spanish Civil War|outbreak of hostilities]] Olot was overtaken by Republican militias, who raided estates belonging to individuals deemed sympathetic towards the Right; according to one version the Llosas’ Mas Quintana mansion in Santa Pau was ransacked, with all movable items robbed and the immovable ones<ref>like massive stone altar in family chapel in Santa Pau</ref> destroyed;<ref>Alber Planas i Serra, ''Guerra civil i repressió franquista a Santa Pau'', [in:] ''Ebre'' 38/4 (2010), p. 107, available [http://www.raco.cat/index.php/ebre/article/viewFile/216264/287036 here]; also Alber Planas i Serra, ''Joan Pinsach i Solé, L’alcalde de Santa Pau afusellat per franquisme'', Barcelona 2009, p. 10</ref> according to another, it was expropriated in an orderly manner.<ref>on September 6, 1936, Planas i Serra 2009, p. 7</ref> Though his age did not save from execution,<ref>among others, also an individual aged 65 was executed by Republican militia in Santa Pau, Planas i Serra 2010, p. 108</ref> he survived the outburst of revolutionary zeal. None of the sources consulted provides information on his whereabouts during the Civil War. Immediately following [[Catalonia Offensive|Nationalist seizure of Catalonia]], in February 1939 Llosas rushed to offer his services to the new Presidente de la Diputación,<ref>''La Vanguardia Española'' 17.02.39, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1939/02/07/pagina-5/33121223/pdf.html here]; the first Nationalist troops, the Navarrese Carlist [[requeté]] units, entered Santa Pau on February 8, 1939</ref> March 1939 entrusted with gathering trade and industry managers of Girona province to proceed with the post-war reconstruction.<ref>''La Vanguardia Española'' 03.03.39, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1939/02/07/pagina-5/33121841/pdf.html here]</ref> However, apart from the very early months of Francoism in Catalonia he was no longer reported as engaged in any official activities. [[File:FrancoenReus.jpg|thumbnail|[[Francoism]] in Catalonia, 1940s]] There is almost no information on Llosas’ public activity in the 1940s and later.<ref>Llosas is not a single time mentioned in post-civil war history of Catalan Carlism, Robert Vallverdú i Martí, ''La metamorfosi del carlisme català: del "Déu, Pàtria i Rei" a l'Assamblea de Catalunya (1936-1975)'', Barcelona 2014, {{ISBN|9788498837261}}</ref> Its key thread was engagement in numerous religious initiatives,<ref>Acctión Católica, Conferencias de San Vicente de Paúl, Junta de la Minerva or Venerable Orden Tercera del Carmen, ''Acció Católica'' 13.01.51,''¡Arriba España!'' 03.12.55, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000277710&page=10 here]</ref> reported as late as the early 1950s.<ref>''La Vanguardia Española'' 04.09.42, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1992/02/16/pagina-7/33104587/pdf.html here]</ref> Another was culture; apart from sporadic public appearances<ref>like delivering public lecture on Vayreda, ''¡Arriba España!'' 25.05.43, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000271232&page=18 here]</ref> he was supplying historical pieces, usually related to religious topics, to the press, mostly to the Girona edition of ''[[:es:Arriba España (periódico)|¡Arriba España!]]'';<ref>the first one identified published in ''¡Arriba España!'' of 11.11.39, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000269776&page=2 here], the last one in ''¡Arriba España!'' 14.07.51, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000274401&page=3 here]</ref> the periodical referred to him as "respectable y querido amigo".<ref>''¡Arriba España!'' 13.05.45, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000272123&page=6 here]</ref> In 1947 he became a great-grandfather,<ref>''¡Arriba España!'' 22.02.47, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000273238&page=4 here]</ref> but since 1949 he remained seriously disabled.<ref>''¡Arriba España!'' 12.03.49, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000273333&page=5 here]</ref> His funeral was attended by president of Diputación Provincial, alcalde of Olot, leaders of provincial [[Movimiento Nacional|Movimiento]] and representatives of Carlism.<ref>''La Vanguardia Española'' 01.12.55, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1935/02/21/pagina-30/32785682/pdf.html here]</ref> His obituary in ''¡Arriba España!'' claimed he had always been a Traditionalist.<ref>''¡Arriba España!'' 03.12.55, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000277710&page=8 here]</ref>

Tríptico sobre las complejas relaciones entre carlismo y catalanismo a fines del siglo XIX'', [in:] ''Historia y Politica'' 14 (2005), p. 45-84 * Josep Clara, ''La Comunió Tradicionalista a Girona (1931-1936), [in:] El Carlisme entra Dues Guerres, 1876-1936'', [in:] ''Revista de Girona'' 1991, p. 83-88 * Lluís Costa Fernández, ''La dictadura de Primo de Rivera a Girona: premsa i societat (1923-1930)'' [PhD thesis Universitat de Girona], Girona 1994, {{ISBN|9788469427996}} * Núria Moret i Llosas, ''El llegat documental de Pere Llosas i Badia'', [in:] ''Annals del Patronat d'Estudis Històrics d'Olot i Comarca'' 1994, pp. 51–66 * Narcís Selles, ''Marian Vayreda: idealització i conflicte davant d'una realitat canviant'', [in:] ''Revista de Girona'' 220 (2003), pp. 30–35
